MCBATH: Thank you. And I yield back.

CICILLINE: I thank the gentlelady for yielding back. I now recognize myself for five minutes.

Professor Teachout, I'd like you to respond to an argument that we have heard during the course of this investigation that--that Congress suddenly becoming active in this antitrust space risks rendering antitrust laws dangerously political and that somehow our efforts to sort of get the policy around antitrust modernized and updated creates some perception that we are politicizing antitrust. I wonder if you'd respond to that argument.

TEACHOUT: Economic policy and anticorruption policy are arguably the core jobs of Congress, protecting the people of this country from tyrants and allowing for a thriving economy. There is recent research that Mr. Rahman alluded to showing that corporate concentration is leading to a transfer of as much as $14,000 per year from workers to investors. This is a major driver of any quality.

Nobody doubts that labor law is your job, that tax law is your job, that campaign finance law is your job. And when it comes to antitrust, antitrust and antimonopoly law is about the country sharing its vision of what a moral, fair, and thriving economy looks like. There is nothing more Congressional than antitrust law.

CICILLINE: I couldn't agree with you more. Thank you. You said it much more articulately than I could have.

Ms. Hubbard, I'd like to now ask you. There obviously is significant reporting that--and--and we're all aware that the state attorneys generals, the FTC, and the DOJ are all pursuing antitrust investigations into the major dominant technology platforms, and some reporting that lawsuits may be filed very soon. Some have also suggested that, you know, Congress should just wait to see how these cases turn out before pursuing legislative reform.

I, of course, have suggested that they are two very different proceedings. One is an enforcement proceeding, which we are not at a--we are not prosecuting an enforcement action. But ours is--as Professor Teachout just mentioned, ours is public policy development and the urgency of doing our work cannot be overstated. And so, of course, we shouldn't await those. I just want to be sure that I'm not a course without thinking.

HUBBARD: Right. And as you know, I was at the New York AG's office, and they're part of these investigations. So, I--I still don't think you should wait for them. And the reason is there is so much conduct--so much anticompetitive conduct to go after that the agencies are just trying to bite off little tiny pieces that they can work on that are just a tiny fraction of the anticompetitive conduct that's going on. So, they're not, you know, getting the whole landscape of all the different ways that these companies are abusing their monopoly power to exclude competition.

The other thing is that antitrust cases take years. So, we have very pressing issues here about small business, about citizens, about democracy, that speech. We need urgent action right now in the middle of this global pandemic. We can't wait five, 10 years for an antitrust case to--to finish up.

CICILLINE: Thank you.

HUBBARD: And the last thing is we have seen some strong antitrust cases lately that the judges just completely screw up. I mean, the New York State AG sued to block the Sprint/T-Mobile merger. That was a classic antitrust case of 3 to 2 major competitors. It should have been blocked. The evidence was overwhelming that it would lead to a price increase under the Chicago School theory of consumer welfare, and they still didn't win.

So, we just can't put this in the--in the hands of the courts. It's too important and too urgent. I do urge those enforcers to carry on and do their job, but we need you as well.

CICILLINE: Thank you. And Professor Rahman, in your written statement you note that tech platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple referees send essential infrastructure just like the railroads, the bridges and telegraph lines of a century ago and you write about the dangers of unchecked private control over social economic and political infrastructure and I wonder if you could just speak a little more about want that kind of infrastructure and the power that accompanies it means and why our responsibility in terms of developing good public policy in this context is so important.

RAHMAN: Thank you very much chairman. I think like a lot of the other speakers today have alluded this--we are in such a crisis moment right now in our country and a central piece of this is that we--if Congress doesn't act what that means is that we are actually living under the Private government as professor Teachout said the private government of these private firms and the misapplication of law that we are seeing from the reports and so the essential infrastructure is exactly that, it is essential if we don't update the rules of the road to make sure everybody can actually access that infrastructure, build businesses and engage in the social activities that it enables then we are not creating the kind of economy that we need to be equitable and inclusive and to create new types of innovation in the future.

CICILLINE: And so if I just asked for all of the witness says as I kind of review both the testimony of this hearing today which has been incredibly useful and your written testimony it seems as if the reforms that you have all recommended are some part of these. They are kind of in five different areas and I want to be sure that I haven't missed one. The first is a change of some presumptions and statutes to shift burdens two parties that both may be engaging in misconduct but also have easier access to the information. Two, this whole notion of separation of lines of business that is sort of structural change so we eliminate what professor Teachout has described as this extraordinary conflict of interest, which is bad for our economy, bad for innovation, bad for a whole range of other things.

Three, more rigorous enforcement which of course we recognize means more resources, staff, and leadership that enthusiastically and creatively promote competition policy and believe in this stuff and will work aggressively. The fourth area is a reversal of a number of court decisions that have either kind of misinterpreted or frankly just changed the intention of Congress as it relates to important competition policy and then fifth a set of provisions that may just explicitly prohibit discriminatory behavior so have I missed, are there other kind of--other--you know and those obviously have some permutations but are there other general areas that we ought to be looking at in this final part of our investigation in terms of recommendation or does that--yes, Mr. Baer?

BAER: I agree with I think that aptly summarizes the points. I do think in looking at prohibitions we also ought to be thinking at forward-looking roles you know interoperability, portability and it may well be we need to invest whether it's Federal Trade Commission or a new agency with the authority to do targeted rules that actually will promote competition so that's kind of an addendum 2.5.

CICILLINE: Great, thank you. I will make that point 6, it deserves its own. Anyone else? Yes, sir? Mr. Kades?

KADES: Yeah, I just want to echo what--what Bill Baer just said. I mean I do think it's really important to think about part of what--

BAER: That's why I promoted you back then.

(LAUGHTER)

KADES: I know. Too often we see when people say regulation they have these--this theory of burdening commerce where in fact regulations is just a kind of jargon way to say these are the rules of the marketplace.

CICILLINE: Right.

KADES: So the FCC right, the reason they decided at some point that long-distance monopoly didn't mean you have to have monopoly on phones know, now you have to have interconnection and I think a lot of the problems we are dealing with whether it be with any of these companies is better regulatory rules really will unleash competition and unleash it along the lines we want to see.

CICILLINE: And I'm just with the indulgence of my colleagues I'm just going to ask Professor Rahman, I think he had his hand up also.

RAHMAN: Yeah, thank you Chairman. Very quickly I just had one piece which is important to clarify that rulemaking authority that the FTC will also need in order to be an effective enforcer going forward of the kinds of issues that we have talked about today. That is a dispute right now and Congress could help implement that.

CICILLINE: Well, I thank you. I have gone way over my time so I appreciate the indulgence.

Before closing today's hearing though I would like to first just think the chairman of the full committee, Chairman Nadler who has been an extraordinary supporter of this investigation and an active participant and it would not have been permitted to proceed in the kind of robust nature that it did without his support so I want to thank Mr. Nadler for that.

NADLER: Let me thank Mr. Cicilline for--for his role in this. Without your efforts this would not have occurred.

CICILLINE: Thank you Mr. Chairman. I also want to take a moment as a point of personal privilege to thank the members of the subcommittee on both sides of the aisle who have taken this work seriously, invested extraordinary amounts of time to conduct a really thorough investigation. I am really grateful for that and also want to take a particular moment of privilege to extend my thanks to our extraordinary staff of the subcommittee for the work that they have done and will continue to do.

I have said this many times before, this is a mighty staff of five or six that has done the work of 30 or more and that is (INAUDIBLE) Nikon(SP), Amanda Lewis(SP), Phil Byrnebot(SP), Anna Lenhart(SP) and Joe Fernbach(SP) and they have just been extraordinary and I know all of my colleagues will join me in thanking them.

(APPLAUSE)

And I think you know they have obviously been really important and indispensable part of this process and every member on this dais is grateful on both sides of the aisle for all of the work that has been put into it. I also want to just take a moment to thank my chief of staff Peter (INAUDIBLE) and my communications director Richly Chetty(SP) for their diligence and commitment during this investigation. And finally, to our witnesses, thank you again.

You have all informed this work throughout and given us a lot to think about today and we are grateful for that and I will end by just reminding everyone the reason that this investigation is so important to the future on our country is because our country has a history of this battle between concentrated economic power, monopolies and democracy. We are seeing that play out in the most extraordinary way and frankly in a dangerous way and it is incumbent on the Congress of the United States to fulfill our responsibility to make sure our economy works and we safeguard our democracy and this investigation is a critical part of that so thank you all. And with that, the hearing is adjourned. I'm sorry, members have five legislative days to enter into the record materials and extended remarks.

Good afternoon, Mr. Chairman, Mr. Ranking Member, and all members of the committee and their staff. My name is Harmeet K. Dhillon, and I am a trial lawyer in private practice in California, with a focus on technology and employment issues. In my 25-year career, I have represented numerous clients subjected to discrimination in academia, the workplace, consumer markets, and in civil rights matters. I have been called before you today to discuss the rampant and systematic discrimination of certain classes of conservative Americans that is occurring within, and perpetrated by, certain elements within the technology industry.

Today, I will endeavor to describe the anti-conservative discrimination, harassment, and institutionalized bias faced by many conservative Americans at the hands of large technology companies. I will begin by discussing Big Tech's discriminatory employment practices, with an emphasis on Google, which I have sued in a class action lawsuit on behalf of conservatives, men, and white or Asian employees and job applicants. n1 Next, I will discuss how Big Tech companies, particularly social media companies, discriminate against conservatives in the products and services they offer. I will also discuss the overt and embedded political biases found at these companies. Finally, I will touch upon the negative impacts of these practices on business innovation, growth, and consumer choice.

I. Big Tech's Employment Practices Discriminate Against Conservatives.

Through my employment law practice, I have learned that Big Tech firms systematically and illegally engage in widespread discrimination against American workers on the basis of their gender, race, religion, values, and political affiliations. Specifically, men, whites, Asians, Christians, those with conservative family values, and political libertarians/conservatives are daily punished for who they are and what they believe. Big Tech companies - even while they compete with one another in certain markets - employ the same tactics in varying degrees: hiring quotas and preferences, and the silencing of questions and heterodox viewpoints through harassment, blacklisting, and firing critics who make it past the employment barricades. Employees who dare to dissent are not only fired, but publicly shamed, humiliated, labeled, and cast out.

James Damore is one such client to have experienced this perverse treatment. James was fired by Google because he dared to share, internally within Google, a memorandum he created in response to his employer's request for feedback. His memo reflects and discusses widely held views, supported by published research, about differences between men and women, and his thoughts about how those differences may be relevant to making the workplace more attractive for women. James fell victim to Big Tech's war of political correctness and social engineering.

Many other workers who dare to speak out against these practices are similarly disciplined, fired, and shunted into secretive arbitration proceedings with limited rights and no appeal. For every James Damore and his colleagues at Google who are publicly seeking protection against these abusive practices, there are thousands more whose names the members of this committee will never hear. Indeed, shortly after I filed the lawsuit on behalf of James Damore Google moved swiftly for a protective order censoring what information may be publicly disclosed in court filings, and by demanding that Damore and two of his colleague's claims be submitted to separate, individual, secretive arbitrations closed off from public view and press reporting. As a result, most of the important employment issues implicated by the Damore lawsuit will never be heard in open court, and both the public and government may never learn the truth of what occurred,or be allowed to consider whether action should be taken to prevent more of the same.

Objection to Big Tech's discrimination comes from more than one political persuasion. I represent a significant cross-section of the American workforce which includes white men, Asian men, libertarians, Republicans, economic conservatives, social conservatives, Christians, and people with no political or lifestyle affiliation whatsoever. Workers who question Big Tech's unworkable and impossibly rigid orthodoxy are criticized, ostracized, demonized, threatened, and fired, often for the smallest and frequently fabricated infractions. Indeed, I have represented employees chastised for a wide variety of innocuous activities, including: asking how to address someone based on their gender preference; joining 62 million other Americans in voting for President Trump; and suggesting that there may be differences between men and women that should be considered in designing a workplace friendlier to women.

The employer's motivation across each of these cases appears to be the same: to impose upon their employees only those progressive values that dictate a redistribution of opportunities and benefits to certain defined classes, with no regard to the human carnage meted on innocent workers who have not, themselves, discriminated against others. I want to be clear, however, that this problem is not restricted to Silicon Valley. The tech giants in California were, as they very often are, the first movers within corporate America to adopt these new, and increasingly aggressive tactics. Unfortunately, they were not the last to do so, and I have spoken with or represented employees across the United States facing similar issues - usually at the hands of America's largest and most successful corporations, where the disease of political correctness has firmly taken root, and is metastasizing

These are career-limiting employment challenges for my clients and many other free-thinking individuals, but they have broader consequences for all of us, in terms of slowed innovation, denial of social media services to many Americans, and ultimately a lack of competitiveness. Simply put, Big Tech's obsession with re-engineering society is costing jobs, information, rights, opportunities, and money. In fact, there is a growing trend within technology companies to increase hiring for "Diversity and Inclusion" departments, taking away resources from economic drivers and instead devoting those resources to making decisions about quotas, executive performance at hitting those quotas, how to punish people who question or fail to meet the quotas, and how to placate the social justice warriors within and outside the corporations.

II. Big Tech's Products Systematically Discriminate Against Conservatives

Big Tech's anti-conservative bias extends far beyond the confines of labor and employment law. The discriminatory attitudes described in this testimony are pervasive and nationwide in scope. Moreover, these attitudes infect the products that Big Tech companies offer their customers, and thus affect American consumer choice. In some markets, such as digital advertising, Big Tech companies have near-monopoly or duopoly power, n13 such that the lack of competition means consumers are stuck with biased and even discriminatory product offerings. The examples are manifold.

III. Big Tech Employees And Managers

Disproportionately Support Democrats For Election

When seeking explanations as to the source of Big Tech's ideological biases, one need look no further than political affiliation, as measured by campaign contributions.

1. Since George H.W. Bush won Napa County in 1988, Republican presidential nominees have lost every county in the Bay Area. n50

2. In 2012, President Obama won 84% of the vote in San Francisco, and raised more money in the Bay Area than in New York or Hollywood. n51

3. In 2016, President Trump received just 9% of the vote in San Francisco. n52

4. These figures represent the ambient liberal bias in the region, but when considered in conjunction with campaign contributions by Big Tech employees and managers, as we did recently, n53 the results are even more extreme:

5. In the 2016 campaign, Google employees gave $31.38 to Democrats for every $1 to Republicans.

6. A stunning 35 times more Google employees contributed to Clinton than Trump.

7. The odds of dying in a pedestrian incident (1 in 647) were greater than the odds of a U.S.-based Google employee having contributed to Donald Trump's 2016 Presidential campaign (1 in 875).

8. Of the 39 Google employees who contributed to Trump, 48.7% did not reside in the Bay Area of California where Google is headquartered. None of Google's Trump supporters listed themselves as executives, and 76.9% of them disclosed that they were in technical roles such as software engineers or developers.

9. In the 2016 presidential election nationally, Google employees contributed to Democrats versus Republicans at 19.9 times the national rate.

10. In the 2016 campaign, Google employees contributed to Hillary Clinton versus Donald Trump at 21.1 times the national rate.

11. Total individual campaign contributions across the U.S. were 60.0% ($672.5 million) to Democratic Party candidates, 38.0% ($425.7 million) to Republican Party candidates, and 2.0% ($21.7 million) to other party candidates.

12. By contrast, Google employees' total individual campaign contributions were 94.7% ($1,986,768) to Democratic Party candidates, 3.0% ($63,319) to Republican Party candidates, and 2.3% ($47,393) to other party candidates.

13. In sum, it is statistically implausible for this level of bias to occur at a company the size of Google without active selection of employees by political views, or the corollary: without active discrimination to drive out conservative or moderate employees. Even a cursory examination of campaign contributions confirms employees, and especially management, of Big Tech to be overwhelmingly in the Democratic party camp.

IV. CONCLUSION

I respectfully submit to this committee that the coordinated, discriminatory actions of the social media giants steer us far away from our Constitution, far away from the rights we hold sacred, and far away from the ideals with which we seek to govern our lives. We hear a great deal about diversity these days. Well, diversity also includes diversity of thought. No one should be fired for the sin of disagreeing with his or her employer about something unrelated to job performance. No one should be denied employment or promotion because he or she was born into a now-disfavored demographic group, or should be made to answer in the workplace for the sins of others who came before them.

Big Tech has become an insular fortress of thought coercion and vindictive behavioral control, where instead of robbing individuals of their lives, it seeks to rob them of their ability to exercise independent judgement and free will. The culture and tactics of some companies would make Orwell's Big Brother proud, as they often surpass the cult-like thinking described in his book 1984. These actions are not just a form of private censorship carried out against isolated individuals or groups by a lone manager or director, but are broad-based attempts to completely reclassify or dispense with reason and logic, and reshape our economy and our society into a progressive, utopian form. This thought control manifests itself in the illegal discrimination against employees, in manipulation of data, in censorship of consumers, and in meddling with our elections, and it should not stand.

Thank you for inviting me to share my views and the experiences of our clients, and I look forward to answering any questions from the committee.

LOUIS DOBBS, FOX NEWS HOST: --joins us tomorrow Pastor Robert Jeffries among our guests. Hope you will join us, a reminder follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, Facebook and Instagram @LouDobbsTonight. Thanks for joining us, good night from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS HOST: Good morning TGIF. Good morning, everyone. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Thanks for joining us. It is Friday, May 29th, your top stories right now 6:00 am on the East Coast.

Riots on the streets of Minneapolis this morning, a police precinct set ablaze as protests over the death of George Floyd intensify there and across the country. We have a live report from the ground coming up.

Meanwhile, President Trump's tweet on the riots flagged by Twitter, the company censoring his post claiming it glorifies violence this after the President signed an Executive Order limiting protections for social media giants.

U.S.-China tensions are raising meanwhile, President Trump say he will hold a news conference today on China after Beijing's moves to clamp down on Hong Kong's freedoms. China is threatening counter measures this morning.

The growing tensions pushing Futures toward a lower opening this morning take a look at stocks, with the DOW Jones Industrial average right now down 100 points, the S&P is down 9 and the NASDAQ down better than 32 points.

This after U.S. markets finished in the red yesterday but for the month, the DOW, the NASDAQ and the S&P 500 are up better than 4 percent on the month of May. Plus, helping America's small businesses, the House is easing rules for the Paycheck Protection Program. "Mornings with Maria" is live right now.

And global markets this morning continue to reflect the concerns going over across the world, concerns about China's action against Hong Kong's freedoms and how the world will react leading to losses across the board in Europe. Take a look. FTSE100 down 58 right now, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 35 and the DAX Index in Germany lower by 127.

In Asia overnight markets were mixed. Investors are waiting for President Trump's press conference and what he has to say about China tightening its grip on Hong Kong. What will be the real repercussions to that?

Markets are mixed as you see SHANGHAI Composite was actually up a quarter of a percent, HANG SENG in Hong Kong down three quarters of a percent. Now some of the top stories that we're watching this morning Minneapolis on fire after another night of violence across the city the National Guard called in after rioters seize the city's third precinct, setting it on fire.

Protesters are demanding charges against the officers involved in the death of George Floyd. The riots sparking protests across the country people want justice. In Denver in riot gear trying to contain angry crowds as they knock down police barriers and vandalize cars.

In New York, at least 40 protesters were arrested after clashing with police there as well. President Trump is promising justice for Floyd while slamming the Mayor of Minneapolis for his handling of looting and rioting in the city the Mayor firing back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JACOB FREY, MAYOR, MINNEAPOLIS: Donald Trump knows nothing about the strength of Minneapolis. We are strong as hell. Is this a difficult time period? Yes. But you better be damned sure that we're going to get through this.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The Mayor claiming he's doing everything he can to control the violence, saying that this is the most difficult thing the city has ever gone through in Minneapolis. President Trump cracking down on social media companies as well the President signing an Executive Order yesterday that curtails legal protections for the company's platforms, accusing them of having an unchecked power to censor.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: My Executive Order calls for new regulations under section 230 of the Communications Decency Act to make it those social media companies that engage in censoring or any political conduct will not be able to keep their liability shield.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act indemnifies companies like Twitter and Facebook for any action taken in good faith. Twitter reacting to the new order tweeting this, this Executive Order is a reactionary and politicized approach to a landmark law.

Section 230 protects American innovation and freedom of expression and is underpinned by Democratic values. Attempts to unilaterally erode it threaten the future of online speech and internet freedoms. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg adding the Executive Order is the wrong move.

Well, President Trump is set to announce new U.S. policies on China at a news conference today. We are all waiting to see what the news conference is. It comes after Beijing approved a new national security law that overrides Hong Kong's autonomy the President adding that he will release more details about the possible impact of the new law on the U.S.-China trade deal to reporters.

You're looking at violence happening in Hong Kong on Wednesday. The President is also expected to sign a bill that punishes China for torturing the Uyghur Muslims which are currently locked up in camps in China at least one million of those Muslims wanting to practice their own religion.

Nine states and Washington D.C. easing several restrictions today D.C. reopening outdoor dining as well as hair salons and barber shops. Illinois, Maryland and Virginia also allowing outdoor seating at restaurants beginning today. In the south sports fans get the go ahead to attend outdoor games this weekend in Texas, then use must limit capacity though to 25 percent.

And a sense of normalcy in Mississippi, Oklahoma and Arkansas, people flocking to restaurants and mall as those states lift restrictions as well. More than 40 million people have filed for unemployment benefit since states issues stay-at-home orders and forced businesses to close. That number has not been seen since the great depression.

Well, markets are pointing to a decline this morning ahead of the opening of trading. Today is the final trading day of what's been a volatile month for the markets, the month of May. Investors are heightened trade tensions with China now on rest in Hong Kong, the reopening of the economy as we move into June a lot of things consider.

Let's talk right now with CFRA Chief Investment Strategist Sam Stovall and also joining the conversation this morning Fox Businesses' Dagen McDowell, Pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners Lee Carter and Real Clear Politics White House Reporter Philip Wegmann. Great to see you everybody this, thanks so much you for being here.

Sam, let's kick it off with you. Give us your assessment of where we are and what things might look like come six months, now that we are seeing all 50 states open and more reopenings of businesses this weekend?

SAM STOVALL, CFRA CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Good morning, Maria. Well, I think what we're going to be experiencing is that V-shaped recovery that economists are calling for, expectations for a 37 percent decline in second quarter GDP followed by a 28 percent surge in the third quarter and a double digit gain in the fourth quarter as well.

And I think that investors realize that the second quarter earnings picture is dismal at minus 44 percent, but expectations are that things could end up coming in better and that's why the market will likely continue to march its way higher.

BARTIROMO: Dagen McDowell.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: Sam, I was looking at a note that U.S. corporate bond sales have hit $1 trillion. They're running at the fastest pace ever and this is without the Federal Reserve even directly buying any fixed income.

Of course, bond ETFs, yes. But this is literally just the Fed being that backstop. How do we solve what many call - I know Stephanie Pomboy is coming up later - a corporate debt bubble with more debt. Is this still a problem months, even years for now, for the stock market?

STOVALL: I think it's something that will be in the background for quite some time. Yes, we're dealing with a debt level that really was unseen before but we realize that it's as if we're in World War II. We've got to be spending the money in order to support the economy.

And I think the Fed basically says that with the monetary stimulus, Congress says with the fiscal stimulus, that the debt is something that we will have to manage later on but right now the focus is on supporting the economy.

BARTIROMO: I tell you, it feels like we've seen the worst in terms of the economic story but you've got a lot of companies that won't make it here, Sam. Coronavirus and the business impact have been significant. Costco now one of the major retailers open during the pandemic reporting higher revenue and an increase in same store sales during the third quarter.

The company also said they are re-evaluating its food sampling once the pandemic ends. One of the most popular features in their stores is coming as UPS is announcing peak surcharges for companies like Amazon and Target. They're sending more packages during the Coronavirus pandemic.

Walk us through the industry here, Sam, that you think will be poised to lead us out of this recovery and which areas do you think that will be taking longer and harder hit?

STOVALL: Right now, we're looking at about 34 percent of the sub industries and there are about 150 sub industries in the S&P 1500, about one-third of them are above the 200 day moving average. So what we're basically seeing are the sectors such as consumer discretionary, we're looking at financials, we're looking at some of the other cyclical areas that are working their way higher as investors anticipate a turnaround.

The best performing groups over the last week were your discount department stores, were your airlines, leisure facilities, et cetera. So the areas that were hit the hardest investors believe if they have not gone out of business already they probably won't and will be able to eek by.

So a lot of those companies that in the hotel hospitality space, et cetera, that we've been quite worried about could end up surviving and representing good investment opportunities.

BARTIROMO: Look, I think the big story this morning is going to be the President's press conference on China. I'm hearing that they're going to go big in some way in terms of holding China accountable for breaking another promise with Hong Kong.

Philip Wegmann, tell me your thoughts on the President's policies and what could come out of this? We may very well see sanctions on individuals from the Communist Party. What else can the President do at this press conference to hold China accountable?

PHILIP WEGMANN, REAL CLEAR POLITICS WHITE HOUSE REPORTER: Well, he could finally tip his hand. For months we've been asking the President and the press corps what kind of repercussions China should face for their lack of transparency when it came to COVID-19 and each time he declined to answer.

He said he would deal with that at a later date. So now after about two and-a-half months of having that question put to him, he's finally going to give us some kind of answer. What I'm looking at right now is the clearest indication of what we can expect is last week Larry Kudlow said that the President was miffed at China.

And that he is no longer as enamored with the possibility of the U.S.-China trade deal. He could perhaps change something in that area perhaps there will be you know human rights elements to this, anything to push back against China. Right now, the mood is very, frankly negative.

BARTIROMO: And by the way just like China pushed ban on the CDC to investigate what's happening in terms of the origins of the COVID-19, they also pushed back on the UN. America's mission to the United Nations revealing that it had requested a Security Council meeting to discuss China's unlawful moves over Hong Kong but as China, one of its most powerful members on the council, blocked that meeting.

So China and the Communist Party not allowing anybody in to see the plans for Hong Kong, just the way they did not allow anyone in to see the origins of Coronavirus. Sam Stovall, thank you for your insights this morning. We're expecting a flat opening this morning for the broader averages. But the rest of the year it's going to be important to watch the economy. Thank you, sir.

Coming up, riots raging across the country this morning over the death of George Floyd, one police station in Minneapolis engulfed in flames right now and at the risk of exploding. We're live in Minnesota when we come back.

The protests fueling a social media fight meanwhile as Twitter takes action against President Trump's tweet overnight again. We're bringing you the very latest. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Social media crackdown, President Trump responding to violent protests in Minneapolis overnight, the President tweeted this. These thugs are dishonoring the memory of George Floyd. I won't let that happen. Just spoke to the Governor Tim and told him that the military is with him all the way. Any difficulty and we will assume control but when the looting starts, the shooting starts. Thank you.

Twitter hid the tweet claiming that it glorified violence, days after flagging the President's tweets on mail-in ballot fraud. Joining me right now is media reporter for the Hill, Joe Concha. Joe it is great to have you this morning, what do you think of this?

JOE CONCHA, THE HILL MEDIA REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. I think that Twitter is probably going to have to hire several thousand more people Maria because if we're just going to be fact checking misleading or lies on Twitter or what is deemed as lies - that last tweet that you just read from the President that is a subjective thing. I don't think that is something that you necessarily would fact check.

Then we better start checking that top Chinese officials are still saying on Twitter that the Coronavirus originated in the United States. We'll have to fact check that Joe Biden, the Presumptive Democratic Nominee said this just yesterday, we're in the middle of a global pandemic and is not only is Donald Trump preventing people from getting the health insurance they need, but he's also actively trying to terminate the insurance millions already have.

So we better start fact checking the Democrat as well as Republican as well as the Chinese as well as, say, the leader of Iran who again called Israel basically a plight on this planet. You're going to have to get a lot of people to fact check a lot of things.

And then you're also going to need the real names of people instead of all these bots that are on that are spreading information as well. That is something that probably I would think, Maria, from a PR perspective Twitter is in big trouble now because you've now alienated half of your potential audience.

The only question is what's the competition? Where are you going to go if Twitter isn't an option?

BARTIROMO: You make really good points, Joe. That's not happening. You've got Twitter targeting the President. You see that tweet that he made about the violence in Minneapolis and yet that - how does that glorify violence? Dagen McDowell, let's talk about this tweet that the President put out and what Twitter is doing right now. What's your take on this?

MCDOWELL: Well, to say when the looting starts the shooting starts, that's disturbing. To call - refer to people as thugs, many would see that as a racist comment. However, Twitter left it up there. It's covered up with a warning but he has left it up there.

President Trump in this instance is his own worst enemy, that he is basically handing Joe Biden win after win, using that kind of language, because the only thing that Vice President Biden has going for him, among a few things, is his empathy and sympathy and people have referred to him as a grief whisperer because of the loss he's experienced throughout his life.

Lee Carter can speak to this. But the President, what is he accomplishing with that kind of language?

BARTIROMO: I mean, look at Twitter. Look what Joe just said. Twitter is now like Mark Zuckerberg said the other day the arbiter of truth. It's ridiculous that they're just focusing on what the President says and no other honesty in any of these other tweets.

MCDOWELL: But Jack Dorsey is not running for President. Jack Dorsey is not running for re-election. Quite frankly, Facebook - Twitter is worth, what, $25 billion. Facebook is worth $651 billion. You mentioned Mark Zuckerberg's comment. Twitter is Zuckerberg's like after lunch snack in terms of its size.

And I think that we place a lot of attention to it but in the grand scheme of things, it's not that important in terms of the scope of social media. But I - you know, the President can say whatever he wants to but I think they--

BARTIROMO: You don't think the president should be remarking about this.

MCDOWELL: --what he said overnight, it doesn't help us grieve. It doesn't help us heal. It doesn't help stop the violence in Minneapolis and in other cities.

BARTIROMO: It's right after Executive Order, Joe. I mean, it comes after the President signed this Executive Order to combat social media censorship. Here's what he said yesterday at the signing. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We're here today to defend free speech from one of the gravest dangers it's faced in American history. The choices Twitter makes when it chooses to suppress and it black lists, shadow bans editorial decisions, pure and simple.

They're editorial decisions. In those moments, Twitter ceases to become a neutral platform and they become an editor with a viewpoint, I think we can say that about others as well, whether looking at Google, whether you're looking at Facebook and perhaps others.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So what about that? I mean, Joe, these liability shields were in place in the Telecommunications Act to assume that a platform, "Would be a neutral actor". Twitter is not neutral.

CONCHA: No, Twitter is not neutral. I mean, think about the people that work at Twitter Maria its basically at Silicon Valley that's a lot of a young people that work there. I doubt there's too many people that lean to the right that work at Twitter and if you look at the political donations from all the big tech companies they're overwhelmingly to Democrats.

Then we look at the head of site integrity, this is the head fact checker over at Twitter. His name is Joe. He has called President Trump on Twitter mind you, a racist tangerine. He said there are actual Nazis in the White House, that's a quote called the Senate Majority Leader McConnell a bag of farts sorry I - breath this right now.

The point is that if this is the person that's doing the fact checking, then you have to assume that the fact checks are going to go one way and we're already seeing it as I pointed out before. You could argue what the President said about Minneapolis, should he have said it or not have said it, that's a political kind of debate.

But for him to make that statement and not to fact check Joe Biden or Adam Schiff, you're going to hire another thousand people for everything that he puts up there. Then that's where you see the unfairness comes from. I just don't know how we handle this after we've gone down this slippery slope in terms of really being fair.

BARTIROMO: All right. Bingo. Joe Concha, thank you sir. We will be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Minneapolis is on fire this morning riots are raging across the city over the death of George Floyd. Officials are warning the third police precinct engulfed in flames could explode. Lee Carter, want to get your take on all of this.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER & PRESIDENT OF MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: Yes. I think that our country is united in one thing. What's happened in Minnesota is absolutely - outrageous and we stand with the city, we stand with the people, and there's so much confusion out there.

I think that what we're seeing right now is this is going to be a moment. Will Smith, when he talked about this, there's always been racism and now it's just being filmed, I think we can't ignore it. I think we can't walk away from this and we have to stand united against this.

It's absolutely outrageous. The news that's breaking now that there are 18 complaints filed against this police officer, we can't stand for this and this has to change and we have to help the city. The city can't - the protests, it's a terrible, terrible thing. You can understand the outrage and the feeling people have right now and we just need to stand and get through this together.

BARTIROMO: I mean do we have any sense of when charges will be brought against the people who killed George Floyd?

CARTER: I don't think that we do at this moment, no.

BARTIROMO: Philip Wegmann.

MCDOWELL: Hey Maria, sorry. I will just add one quick thing that the Justice Department is looking into this in terms of federal charges against not just this one police officer, but the four police officers that were involved in George Floyd's death, murder.

The bar there is high in terms of bringing charges the burden of proof. You have to prove that George Floyd's constitutional rights were also violated. But it's important to note that the Justice Department is on that case.

But historically, in recent instances of police violence in the murder of individuals or the death of individuals, that the Justice Department has not been - has not or chosen not to bring federal charges. But that is part of the justice that people expect and certainly would help with healing.

BARTIROMO: Definitely for sure. We'll take a break. When we come back, we are looking at cities in crisis this morning. San Francisco enforcing socially distancing campsites for the homeless population and it's sparking a fresh debate over the city's spiraling housing crisis.

We'll take a closer look at the controversy as its gotten worse with COVID- 19. Then the hospitality industry, one of the hardest hit amid COVID-19, how the industry is adapting as America begins reopening once again. Stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS HOST, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Welcome back. Good Friday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Friday, May 29th. Your top stories right now, 6:31 a.m. on the East coast.

Growing tensions between the United States and China coming to a boiling point. It is putting pressure on futures this morning. We're expecting a lower opening for the broader averages. Dow futures down 86, S&P down 7 and NASDAQ futures down 21, on this the last day of the month. This after US markets finished in the red yesterday for the month. The Dow, the NASDAQ and the S&P 500 up, better than four percent on the month. As you can see, yesterday's close was a decline of 147 points.

Global markets this morning also showing some weakness. Concerns over Beijing's actions against Hong Kong's freedoms and how the world will react leading to losses across the board. European indices down. FT100 down 57. Quatre Quarante in Paris down 35 and the DAX Index in Germany lower by 104. Consumer prices in the Eurozone coming in at 1/10th of a percent for Month of May. That is a four year low. It is well below the European Central Bank's target of almost two percent.

In Asia overnight markets were mixed there. Investors are awaiting to hear what President Trump has to say. He is holding a news conference this morning about China, and we expect it to be China deepening its grip on Hong Kong and action to be taken as a result of that.

History will be made again at this year's Boston Marathon. Meanwhile, Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: That's right Maria. Good morning. So, for the first time in its 124 year history, the Boston Marathon has been cancelled. The race was originally supposed to be held April 20th. Then it was postponed until September due to COVID-19 concerns, but the Mayor says it will not be safe enough this Fall. Instead, this year for the first time ever, it's going to be a virtual race, which is quickly becoming the new trend for runners. Runners who verify that they ran 26.2 miles on their own within six hours can still get a medal and there will be several virtual events and activities during race week. That's going to be September 7 through the 14th. Get your Strava app uploaded runners.

Alright, Nordstrom, like many other retailers, has been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic. Quarterly sales plunged 40 percent in the company's latest quarter, but Nordstrom says its finances are strong enough to work through the outbreak. About 40 percent of Nordstrom stores are actually now open. And William-Sonoma reported breakout growth in its online sales late in the first quarter and those sales are accelerating now. Same store sales unexpectedly rose by more than 2 1/2 percent. Shares of both companies are higher. While Nordstrom's was higher, it actually just ticked lower, it's about 1/2 percent down now. William-Sonoma still in the green, though, and look at that, it's up almost eigth percent. Strong numbers, really, from William-Sonoma.

And finally, here's a look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com. The NBA's highest paid players. Steph Curry and Chis Paul top the list for the 19, 2020 season. Most expensive beach towns in the US offer luxury for a price. Massachusetts and Florida dominate the top five. And finally, this one, it's a good one. Happy marriages encourage creativity and innovation at work. When workers are happy in their marriages, they have positive spillover of psychological resources into that work. Maria, an unhappy marriage, well researches say, it has the opposite effect. There you go.

BARTIROMO: Makes sense. Alright Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, helping the backbone of America's economy. We are looking at House lawmakers approving changes to the Paycheck Protection Program today. Giving it more latitude in an effort to help small businesses. Loan recipients now only have to spend 60 percent of the funds on payroll, as opposed to the original 75 percent. Borrowers also have 24 weeks to spend the money, up from 8 weeks. The bill now headed to the Senate for approval. This is something certainly I've been railing on. I'm glad that they're making this change, because this is going to make it easier for small businesses to actually get through this. Joining us right now is the former President and CEO of CKE Restaurants, Andy Puzder. Andy, it's great to have you this morning. What's your reaction to these changes on the Paycheck Protection Program plan?

ANDY PUZDER, FORMER PRESIDENT AND CEO, CKE RESTAURANTS: It's great to see you Maria, and the changes are great. They're just what was needed. You had to spend your loan funds.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

PUZDER: 75 percent on payroll, which obviously, employee salaries. And you had to do it within eight weeks. Well, with the economy shut down, you know, with nobody going to work, with customers not showing up at the restaurants, it was very difficult for businesses to meet those deadlines. So, they've extended the time in which you have to spend the money to 24 weeks. And they lowered the amount you have to spend on payroll down to 60 percent, so now people can pay rent and utilities and other expenses. So, it is very positive for the restaurant industry in particular.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, the only other issue that we're still waiting on whether or not we're going to see change is the unemployment benefit of the $600 dollars being given to people who are staying home, ultimately meaning that some people are going to be making more money to stay home than they are actually to go back to work. Do you think we'll see a change there?

PUZDER: God, you know, I hope not. I hope that expires in July. It's gone on longer than it needed to go on. We need people going back to work. You can't pay people not to work and then complain about a high unemployment rate, which is what the people who support extending the benefit seem to want to do. We need that benefit needs to end. People need to get to back to work. We need to start to normalize the economy.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, restaurants were sounding the alarm on all of these programs. Owners across the country saying that COVID-19 precautions, social distancing and putting caps on the number of customers could wipe them out, Andy. So, how serious is this concern? I mean, when you don't have the foot traffic and you know this firsthand, you know, how much of an issue is this for the bottom line? You're talking about these companies living on cash flow and they don't have any right now Andy.

PUZDER: Well, let me tell you, it depends by sector, Maria. And this is not something that's out there very broadly yet, so I'm glad I get to talk to you about it. But, the quick service, the fast food restaurant CEO's that I've talk to, my friends in the industry, are telling me that their sales are positive over last year. So, they're doing better than they were doing before the pandemic, because not only because the third party deliver service, which is up. But the drive throughs. Quick service restaurants have drive throughs. And if you go by a quick service restaurant, you'll see the drive through is packed. Now, fine dining restaurants that count on dining rooms being packed and people ordering steaks and bottles of wine, they're going to have a problem with social distancing. They're going to have a problem with it even when the economy reopens. If they can't fill their restaurants, they'll have problems. But right now the quick service industry seems to be doing pretty well.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, what about this coronavirus tax proposal in California? The state weighing a levy on some of its largest businesses to raise money for the COVID-19 relief legislation. Andy, this is billionaire's Peter Thiel and Elon Musk, consider taking their own companies elsewhere. They say we'll move out. What's your reaction?

PUZDER: Well, it's like the unemployment insurance benefits. You know, paying people not to work. At a time when we need jobs, when people need to return back to work, the unemployment rate in California's about 15 percent. They need people going back to work, so what do they do, they want to tax jobs. I mean it makes absolutely no sense. Businesses like Tesla, like Peter Thiel's company, will leave the state. Our business left California because it was unfriendly before all of this. Now there will be other companies leaving. And secondly, employees don't have to work in California anymore. If you work for one of these Silicon Valley companies and you can work remotely, you can live in Lake Tahoe on the Nevada side. You don't even have to be in California, so you can avoid state income tax and your company won't have to pay the head tax. They've tried this in Seattle.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

PUZDER: Starbucks and Amazon objected and threatened to move. It didn't work. It's a terrible idea, but it's a typical California idea. Let's kill businesses and then expect them to pay more in taxes. It doesn't make any sense.

BARTIROMO: Yeah right. Any, real quick before you go. When we get out of this pandemic and this shutdown altogether, do you think the restaurant business will look a lot different given the fact that, you know, people behavior will likely change? They're going to want to social distance even more. And what's the expense of that? How much expense are these restaurants going to be taking on to retrofit and change the way their setups are?

PUZDER: Well, you're going to have to, again, with fine dining, with sit down restaurants, there's going to be a lot of change, there will be a lot of expense. There won't be as many people in the dining rooms. So, there going to have to increase prices.

BARTIROMO: Okay.

PUZDER: If they're going to stay open, they're going to have to increase their prices.

BARTIROMO: I see.

PUZDER: Quick service restaurants, they're doing fine. They may even do better with just drive through. They don't really need the dining rooms.

BARTIROMO: Alright, we'll expect prices then. Andy, it's good to see you this morning as always. Thank you, sir.

PUZDER: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Andy Pudzer joining us there.

PUZDER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Quick break and then cities in crisis. San Francisco enforcing socially distancing campsites for its homeless population. It is sparking a fresh debate over the cities spiraling housing crisis. We take a closer look at the controversy. We took the show to San Francisco. We're going to show you what we found. And then American's eager to get back to work. What's at stake for small business as the nation fights to safely reopen. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well the homeless crisis in San Francisco, residents now poised to sue the city to stop officials from opening a sanctioned homeless camp in a vacant city lot. They claim it could destroy businesses and put people at risk of contracting the coronavirus. Earlier this year I was in San Francisco reporting on the homeless problem. We got on the ground. We got insight into the growing problem with Alan Byard, a private officer patrolling the streets, take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: How do you think they got to this, officer, I mean, when you look at the number of homeless here, how did they get there?

ALAN BYARD, PRESIDENT, SAN FRANCISCO SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION: People lose their jobs. They get hurt. They, you know, get kicked out from their family. There's a lot of reasons behind it. They have a mental problem that they don't think that they have, but other people are telling them that they do have. You see how they completely blocked the sidewalk. And somebody with a wheelchair can't even get down the sidewalk, because the tents are in the way.

BARTIROMO: What a shame. I mean, you grew up here. You've worked on the job 43 1/2 years. This has to be somewhat personal to you, because this is your city.

BYARD: It is. It is my city. I don't like what I see. I don't like that there's no accountability for what they do.

BARTIROMO: They can't be put in jail just for being on the street.

BYARD: No. No, the Supreme Court says you can sleep on the street.

BARTIROMO: Where do they get the drugs? I mean, what about the drug dealers? They can't be held accountable either?

BYARD: Not in this city. The homeless know that they can come here. The criminals know that they can come here and the odds of them getting arrested are very very low.

BARTIROMO: We've traveled now to Pacific Heights, San Francisco. This is a residential area. It's obviously much cleaner, and calm and quiet. Where families are living here. But it's only a mile and half away from where the heavy tents are in downtown San Francisco. And crime and homelessness. So, the worry is, is that the crime will infiltrate into this area and the tents will follow.

BYARD: This is part of my beats up here. This is a part of the city that a lot of tourists don't see. They see the homeless on TV. They hear about the stories. They don't come up here and see this. This is absolutely wonderful area. These are all working people too. You know, they leave their homes every day and go to work. Come back every night, they have families to raise. They just want to be safe. They want to have a nice place to raise their kids, just like everybody else does. You know, I see it getting worse before it gets better. City Hall has to change.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now, San Francisco politician, former Mayoral candidate, Richie Greenberg. Richie, thanks very much for being here. What do you say about the problem, which seems to be getting worse? How did this start, and how do you handle all of this homelessness on the street?

RICHIE GREENBERG, SAN FRANCISCO POLITICIAN, FORMER MAYORAL CANDIDATE: Well, thank you again for having me here. It's a pleasure. It's a multifaceted problem. We've had a tradition over decades of welcoming people who are the downtrodden. And that's been ingrained in the political life for as long as I've been alive. The difference now, though, is that there seems to be a much more influential activists, homelessness outreach organization activism. And they want to keep their pockets lined. They want to keep in business. They want to make sure that their employees and their headquarters are nice. They lobby, they put ballot measure on the ballot and they do what they can under (INAUDIBLE), not the best circumstances in terms of misleading the voters to vote for ballot measure, and this is what happens, you know.

BARTIROMO: How much of this is because of policies? How much of this is because of policies, San Francisco is a sanctuary city. The policies in many cases blow off Federal policy when it comes to immigration. Is that part of this? The policies in San Francisco are doing the people wrong frankly.

GREENBERG: Absolutely. Correct. Absolutely. And I'll give you one example. It's how the drug dealers themselves are most likely illegal aliens. They're not, they're undocumented. They shouldn't necessarily be here. They have broken laws to get here and these dealers themselves are the ones that are fueling the addicted, homeless. And because of sanctuary city policy, they, themselves, would not necessarily be arrested, turned over to ICE, and this is a big problem.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

GREENBERG: In fact, what we're find now is that the local politicians, City Hall, the Mayor, the Board of Supervisor, which is our City Council, they don't even mention the word drug dealers. They won't even address it. Not at all.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. I mean, the Mayor, she London Breed, announced a staggered reopening of the city, beginning June 15. It includes a modified reopening of businesses and outdoor activities like fitness classes. Will the homelessness affect the reopening, because SanFran is charting its own course on how to reopen, differentiating itself from the other five bay area counties? What do you think?

GREENBERG: Yeah, you're right as well. And certain areas of this city, what's called district six, and that is the tenderloin area that's Soma south of Market, that's the most heavily hit. That's the area that has the most number of tents. The most number of mentally ill and drug addicts that in the tents on the street, blocking the streets. They block storefronts. They block residents. The block condos. A lot of residents in that area feel that they are trapped within their own home. They have families, there are kids that are afraid to actually venture out onto the street to get to parks, for example.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

GREENBERG: And this is really problematic as well. I mean, its a compounding problem.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

GREENBERG: That the COVID, the virus has actually exacerbated multiple times.

BARTIROMO: Sure. And you would expect that. You get thrown this curve ball. You've got to deal with it, but when you've already got bad policies in place, and have this homeless problem. It's going to get worse. Richie, thank you. We'll keep checking back. Richie Greenberg there. Stay with us. We've got a lot to come. We have full panel reaction to the ongoing crisis in San Francisco. What's being done to stop it. So stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well the city of San Francisco struggling to control its homeless crisis. I walked the streets to see it for myself earlier this year. Moments ago, we showed you on the ground footage. Dagen McDowell, you've lived in San Francisco. How different is what you're seeing today on these pictures from when you lived there?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: It's worse, Maria, but the problem of these homeless encampments was a problem 20 years ago when I lived in San Francisco. It's been a problem there and some other major cities for literally decades. This is what happens when government officials, local officials don't do anything about it, and they act like its okay. Many of these individuals, its not an issue of affordable housing, which seems to be a crutch that many people use, it is because they are dual diagnosis individuals. They have both mental illness and drug or alcohol addiction problems. And this issue, nationwide, goes really back to the early 60s, and the beginning of the deinstitutionalization of the mentally ill in this country. They weren't in institutions. They were left out and put in outpatient treatment. But, this, done for the right reason, but it's headed in the wrong direction, where people who are at risk to themselves or others and gravely mentally ill and drug and alcohol addicted are not getting treatment.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MCDOWELL: Instead, they're living on the street, and it's tragic.

BARTIROMO: And we should point out that California's 12th Congressional District is a Congressional District represented by Speaker Nancy Pelosi. She's been representing that district since 2013 at least in San Francisco.

Still ahead my interview with President Donald Trump, Presidential Campaign Adviser Lara Trump next hour. She's going to give us some details on what she's expecting for the convention when we come right back. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5WKH-7GH1-JCRW-50P5-00000-00House lawmakers square off over Facebook's crypto plans2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:51ZLexisNexisHouse lawmakers square off over Facebook's crypto plansNeil Haggerty

WASHINGTON - While lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have concerns about Facebook's proposal to create a global digital currency, there was a sharp divide Wednesday about whether it should be allowed to move forward with the project.

On the one side, Democrats repeated calls for Facebook to immediately halt its Libra plans.

"Will you stop kind of dancing around this question and commit here in this committee before the duly elected representatives of the American people to a moratorium until Congress enacts an appropriate legal framework to ensure that Libra and Calibra do what you claim it is intended to do, which is to serve the public's good?" House Financial Services Committee Chairwoman Maxine Waters, D-Calif., asked David Marcus, the head of Facebook's digital wallet.

But Republicans said Congress has no right to stifle potential innovation.

"Washington must go beyond the hype and ensure that it's not the place where innovation goes to die," said Rep. Patrick McHenry, R-N.C., the panel's top Republican. "Some politicians want us to live in a permission-based society. ... Those are the politicians who would rather kill it before it grows."

Marcus told the committee that he would commit to ensuring that Facebook satisfies regulatory concerns, but stopped short of committing to stop the Libra project until Congress fully investigates its plans.

"I agree with you that this needs to be analyzed, understood, and the proper oversight needs to be set up before Libra can launch," Marcus said, responding to Waters. "And this is in this spirit that we released a white paper very early, before any launch, so that we could have the time to engage with all of the proper regulators and central banks and lawmakers to ensure that we will get this right. And this is my commitment to you, chairwoman. We will take the time to get this right."

When Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., went further to ask Marcus if Facebook would conduct a pilot for Libra limited to "no more than one million users," Marcus said only that he would remain in contact with regulators.

"Congresswoman, we will continue to engage with regulators and the working group at the G-7 that is notably looking after the issues that you raise to ensure that however we launch this it is responsibly and it is with the appropriate oversight and in a very responsible way," Marcus said.

Maloney said that if Facebook does not commit to conducting a pilot program for Libra, then "Congress should seriously consider stopping this project from moving forward."

Waters has already floatedlegislation to block big tech companies from operating as banks.

But Republicans on the committee echoed McHenry's comments, and said Congress should allow the private sector to innovate.

"There's always a presumption that the private sector innovating is a bad thing," said Rep. Andy Barr, R-Ky. "I think the presumption should be totally reversed. I think we should presume that innovation is good. It presents enormous opportunity for financial inclusion, reducing friction in transactions. The opportunities that are created by this innovation is laudable. It's to be commended. That's not to say we shouldn't ask questions, but the presumption in this hearing room today seems to be in the wrong place."

Lawmakers' concerns on Marcus'second daytestifying on Capitol Hill ranged from the cryptocurrency's potential to be used for illicit finance to questions about how Libra should be defined by regulators.

Rep. David Scott, D-Ga., said Facebook's white paper did not properly address how Libra would comply with anti-money-laundering laws.

"I want to call your attention to the fact that neither your white paper nor your subsequent Facebook posts offered any concrete details as to how you plan to implement or enforce strong anti-money-laundering, how you plan to enforce know-your-customer protections and, most importantly, to ensure " the safety of our financial system," Scott said.

Marcus said Libra will register with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, which has an AML regime in place.

Other lawmakers raised questions about what type of product Libra is. While Marcus continuously said that Libra will be a "payment tool," some lawmakers questioned whether it is potentially just an investment instrument.

"This looks to me exactly like an exchange-traded fund backed by a series of short-term instruments and foreign currency, it looks exactly like an ETF," said Rep. Jim Himes, D-Conn. "The SEC says if you have a security that is backed " by other securities you are an exchange traded fund."

Marcus told Himes that Libra is backed by "mainly currencies" and that "no one will buy Libra as an investment."

Rep. Warren Davidson, R-Ohio, further suggested Libra could be regulated as a security.

"You intend to have it pegged to not just a bundle of currencies, but in the white paper, short-term securities," Davidson said. "Well currently under U.S. law, if you're trading in securities as the underlying basis for the asset that you're selling, that's regulated as a security. Why would it not be considered a security?"

Marcus again said that Facebook does not believe Libra would be a security "because it is designed as a payment tool."

Meanwhile, several committee Republicans questioned whether Facebook would make Libra available to users independent of their political views - even if those views are controversial.

Rep. Sean Duffy, R-Wis., noted that Facebook has barred controversial figures like Milo Yiannopoulos and Louis Farrakhan from its platform.

"With regard to your network, can Milo Yiannopoulos or Louis Farrakhan use Libra?" Duffy asked. "Both those two individuals have been banned from Facebook."

Barr urged Marcus to ensure that Libra is a neutral financial platform.

"To the extent that Facebook and other social media enterprises have been criticized for political bias, I think that's important, to earn the credibility of the American people that this platform, this financial platform, be viewed and earn the confidence as a neutral player so that the adoption can serve all and really serve that ultimate purpose of financial inclusion," Barr said.

urn:contentItem:5WB0-MVK1-DYHJ-301N-00000-00House looks at tech's effect on news industry2019-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:58:50ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B,8,999House looks at tech's effect on news industryBy Cecilia KangNew York TimesABSTRACT

Congress opened its antitrust investigation of big tech Tuesday with a hearing focused on how platforms like Facebook and Google may have harmed publishers by siphoning off profits from news organizations.

BODY

WASHINGTON — Congress opened its antitrust investigation of big tech Tuesday with a hearing focused on how platforms like Facebook and Google may have harmed publishers by siphoning off profits from news organizations.

Lawmakers will hear testimony from executives at News Corp, the owner of The Wall Street Journal and other publications; The Atlanta Journal-Constitution; and the News Media Alliance, a trade group representing 2,000 news organizations, including The New York Times.

Matthew Schruers, vice president of the trade group Computer and Communications Industry Association, will represent the tech industry.

The media executives are expected to tell members of the House Judiciary Committee, which is holding the hearing, that big tech platforms have decimated the news industry, leading to a decline in profit and the shuttering of hundreds of local newspapers.

"The rise of digital news distribution has introduced new, potentially existential threats to the news industry," David Chavern, chief executive of the News Media Alliance, wrote in prepared testimony. "Specifically, the emergence of dominant tech platforms as intermediaries between news organizations and their audiences threatens to bring to naught the news industry's investments in a digital future."

Congress' scrutiny of big tech comes amid a swell of recent events challenging the dominance of big tech. The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission recently divided oversight over Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google, increasing scrutiny of the tech giants and how their businesses may be harming rivals and consumers. European regulators have already taken a tough stance against the titans of Silicon Valley, investigating companies for how they handle user data, police speech, and limit competition.

The House committee plans several hearings, depositions, and interviews with competitors over the next 18 months as part of its investigation.

Representative David Cicilline, a Rhode Island Democrat, leading the investigation, has said it would explore a diverse range of issues related to the industry. He said it would look into whether the dominant social network, Facebook, had harmed consumers with its handling of data, for example. He said it also planned to look into whether Amazon had harmed smaller retailers.

Tuesday's hearing gives publishers a platform after years of complaining about big tech's. The News Media Alliance has argued that Facebook and Google have become the biggest online advertising companies at the expense of publishers, which now rely on the platforms to find audiences.

The hearing is expected to focus in part on a bill introduced by Cicilline and Representative Doug Collins, Republican of Georgia, that would give publishers the ability to jointly negotiate with Google, Facebook, and other platforms for better terms. The law would exempt the publishers from antitrust rules for four years, protecting publishers from charges of price collusion.

Cicilline said in his opening remarks that 2,900 reporters and other news staff had lost their jobs this year and that news ad revenue had dropped to $15.6 billion in 2017 from $49 billion in 2006.
